III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/8/23 Supervisor 1 allegedly choked Youth J.
Investigation DCWL was assigned this investigation reported by Complainant,
also the Director, on 8/22/23. Complainant said she heard about it
second-hand from a contractual therapist who heard Youth J
express the allegation in open court.
Youth J was referred to the facility by the Community
Management Organization (CMO).
I contacted Director requesting video of the incident, documents,
and staff schedules.
I collaborated with Government Worker via email.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
On 8/23/23, I arrived at the facility accompanied by Government
Worker. I viewed a voluntary safety arrangement authored by
Government Worker and signed by Director agreeing that pending
the outcome of the investigation, Supervisor 1 will be shadowed
by a staff person not involved in this investigation and if he is
observed restraining inappropriately or attacking any youth,
Director will contact the police, DCWL and Government Worker
immediately.
Video of Pod 1 dayroom
17:21:47 – 17:34:11 – Youth J is in the dayroom with five or six
staff and four youths. Youth J is verbally and physically
aggressive, darting around shirtless, throwing chairs and a trash
can across the room. Staff start removing chairs from the area.
Youth J picks up another chair, runs toward Youth M and throws it
at him. Youth M and J start fighting. Staff are verbally
intervening, separate the two youths and escort Youth M to his
room. Youth J walks into an adjoining classroom and several staff
try to keep him there to protect others, but they are unsuccessful.
Youth J returns to the dayroom.
17:34:12 – 17:35:10 – Supervisor 1 enters the pod. He and Staff
2 initiate a two-person Primary Restraint Technique (PRT) wall
hold on Youth J.
2

17:35:10 – 17:35:12 – Staff 2 releases his hold and Supervisor 1
uses a one-person PRT to escort Youth J to his room locking the
door behind him.
I interviewed Youth J jointly with Government Worker. He said he
was admitted to Lincoln Center in April 2023, and transferred to
Calumet Center in May 2023. Youth J was not interested in
talking to investigators. He said what happened “is not a problem”
and admitted he was “acting out, out of control, antagonized, bit a
staff and assaulted three people.” Further Youth J insisted “I
didn’t get choked. I got put in my room, that’s it.”
I interviewed Supervisor 1 jointly with Government Worker. He
has worked at the facility for five years and been a supervisor for
four. Government Worker read the allegation aloud. Supervisor 1
recalled the incident that occurred six weeks prior. “I was called to
Calumet that they needed my assistance. I got there and Youth J
was hostile. He gestured. About to swing on me. Staff 2 blocked.
We (Supervisor 1 and Staff 2) restricted Youth J’s mobility. I felt
his breathing go down. He relaxed. I walked him to his room and
locked it. I let him out five minutes later. We talked at his door. I
allowed him to shower.” Supervisor 1 denied ever choking Youth
J.
Supervisor 1’s personnel file was reviewed. On 3/31/22 he was
suspended for two days for improperly restraining a youth, failing
to document it and failing to ensure the youth was examined by a
medical professional.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker. She
has worked at the facility for six years, four as a supervisor.
Supervisor 2 was on the pod when she said Youth J was
“assaultive and out of control.” “Youth J walked up and pushed
Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 and Staff 2 held him until he calmed
down. Supervisor 1 escorted him to his room.” Supervisor 2 said
Supervisor 1 did not mishandle or choke Youth J. On the
contrary, she said, they have a good rapport.
I interviewed Supervisor 3 jointly with Government Worker. She
has worked at the facility for four years. Supervisor 3 was present
when she said Youth J was “throwing food and going crazy.” “We
tried to calm him. Youth J pushed and swung at Supervisor 1.
Supervisor 1 and Staff 2 held him, then walked him to his room…I
didn’t see no one get choked or bit.”
3

I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker. He has
worked at the facility nearly six years. Government Worker read
the allegation aloud. Staff 2 responded “No sir. Youth J wasn’t
choked out. He had no trouble breathing and no respiratory
situation whatsoever.”
Staff 2 explained that Supervisor 1 came to the pod to assist and
“Youth J was full steam.” “He swung on Supervisor 1 and was
aggravated. We held him. He finally complied and went to his
room. A few minutes later, Youth J apologized to the pod, me and
Supervisor 1. He showered and that was it.”
Analysis Based on video and interviews of Youth J and staff, there is no
evidence that Supervisor 1 choked Youth J.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
